description.p: A light duty autopistol used as a hold-out and "lady's gun".
The ubiquitous "Polymer-one-shot" cheap plastic pistol. Availble in designer colours.
Cheap Hong Kong knockoff, often used by boosters and other street trash.
Another Dai Lung cheapie, built for the Street.
A well-made autopistol with good range and accuracy. A professional's gun.
A sturdy Solo's gun, used as a standard military sidearm in the U.S. and E.C.C.
It's cheap. It's powerful. It blows up sometimes. What else do you want?
Rugged, reliable, with excellent stopping power. Another fine E.C.C. product from the United Germanies.
Now the standard officer's sidearm for the U.S. Army, the M-2000 served well in the Central American Wars.
Designed as an alternate to the 1998 U.S. Army sidearm trials. A solid contender.
Uzi's entry into the 21st century, all plastic, with a rotary electric clip and adjustable trigger. The choice for many security Solos.
Heckler & Koch's updating of the MP-5K classic, with compound plastics and built in silencing.
An updated version of the venerable Tech Assault I, features larger clip, better autofire, no melting. Honest.
The standard Arasaka Security weapon, found worldwide. A good, all around weapon.
A light composite submachinegun with integral sights. Used by many Euro Solos.
Sternmeyer's best entry in the anti-terrorist category, with wide use on C-SWAT teams and Psycho Squads.

Possibly the most used Solo's gun in existence, the MPK-11 can be modified into four different designs, including a bullpup configuration, standard SMG, an assault carbine, and a grenade launcher mount.
Updated MAC-10, with composite body and cylinderical feeding magazine.
A plastic and carbon fiber update of the AKM, distributed throughout the remains of the Soviet Bloc.
A light, all purpose update, similar to the M-16B.
The standard NATO assault weapon for battlefield work. Bullpup design, collapsing stock.
Another Soviet retread, with improved sighting and lightened with composites.
A high powered auto-shotgun with lethal firepower. Used by Arasaka worldwide. Another good reason to avoid the Boys in Black.
Light duty stakeout shotgun, used by city police departments.
The cyberpyscho hunter's favourite. Almost 2 metres long, this "cannon" fires a depleted uranium shell at super-sonic speeds. Heavy AP sub-caliber penetrator damges armour 2pt/hit.
The third generation of the Stinger missile launcher, this shoulder arm fires one missile.
Shoulder-mounted, rocket-powered grenade launcher. Heavily used in the Central American conflicts under the name of RPG-A.
Thrown.
Grey block of plastique, can be detonated by timer, tripwire or signal.
Can be detonated by timer, tripwire, signal or motion detector.
Liquified napalm sprayer. Back mounted and bulky. Does extra damage following initial hit. (See FNFF, pg.110)
Thrown.
Thrown.
Thrown.
Thrown.
Thrown.
Launcher may be attached (underbarrel) to any assault rifle, or hand-held. Not compatible with Militech RPG-A.
Flashlight sized microwave projector. See FNFF, pg 108 for details.
Milspec laser cannon, rarely seen. See FNFF, pg. 108 for details.
Lightweight, plastic, compressed air powered. Can be doped with drugs, poison. See FNFF, pg 107 for details.
A squirtgun. Yes, a powered squirtgun. See FNFF, pg 108 before you laugh.
Paintball gun from hell. Can fire acid, paint, drugs, poison. See FNFF, pg. 107.
Zap. About the size of a small hand flashlight. See FNFF, pg. 107 for details.
Gyrobalanced, stabilized compound bow. Silent & deadly.
Plastic and bimetal crossbow. Silent, deadly, and you usually get your ammo back.
Mono-sectional crystal blade. Incredibly sharp. In the Japanese "tanto" style. Also available in a naginata form for 100.00 extra.
Sword length version of monoblade. Resembles a hightech katana with a milky, nearly transparent blade.

Heavy gauntlets that cover the entire hand and forearm, articulated with artificial muscle and hydraulics. A Battleglove delivers 3d6 crushing, 2d6 punching damage, and has three spaces for any standard cyberarm weapon or option, except Hydraulic Rams.
Range is "Throw"
Designed for the US Border Patrol use, the Combat Magnum is a popular choice among police officers. Its "small frame" and reliable action make it a best seller.
An excellent .44 revolver, used in home defence and police work. It's long barrel makes it hard to conceal.

The gun "that won the West", the .45 was the most common US sidearm throughout the 1800's. A single action weapon, it must be cocked before firing, although later models had a flattened hammer allowing the gun to be fired by "fanning" the hammer.

The most commonplace police weapon for many years, the Colt .38 has many variants, including the smaller "Chief's Special". With their high reliability, there are many of these guns still in circulation.
A bullpup configured SMG designed to be fired one handed. The Bushmaster uses the M-16A1 clip, making it technically closer to an assault rifle than a submachinegun.
Standard NATO rifle. A very deadly assault weapon; durable and handles well.

Standard Soviet military rifle, exported worldwise, particularly to Soviet client-states. Reliable, rugged, but rather difficult to control, the AK-47 is probably the most well-known weapon of its type in the world.

Standard US military rifle since the 1960's, the M-16 has high accuracy and a staggering ROF. A built in "tumble" effect comphensates for the light 5.56 round. Earlier M-16 models were cantankerous and unrealiable in the extreme, with an accuracy of 1, not 2. The AR-15 and the AR-180 are civilian models used by police and home defence.

A bullpup configured rifle using high tech plastics and aluminum, the AUG is the wave of the future. The scope is built in, giving it great accuracy, while its rugged plastic construction gives it reliability and strength.
A basic scoped hunting rifle, used to hunt deer.
Close in Assault Weapon, designed for house to house work, crowd suppression. Scope is built in, making it very accurate for type.
Designed as a "holdout" for law enforcement agents, the COP uses a unique revolving firing pin arrangement. It's small size makes it easily hidden.
Developed by the Israelis as a reliable export weapon, the UZI is used worldwide by security forces, the US Secret Service, police and (unfortunately) terrorists and drug dealers.

A standard military sidearm for the Soviet Bloc, the Skorpion is the world's smallest military SMG. It's small ammunition size gives it excellent controllability. It is easily silenced and can be carried in a shoulder holster.
A very small SMG used by covert units and terrorists. It can be easily silenced. Howeer, it's very large ammo size makes it very difficult to control when on full auto.
Two examples of the H&K family of interchangeable SMGs, both share parts and design similarities. The MP5K is a very small version of the MP55D3, which has a built in silencer.
Standard US military SMG during WWII, the Thompson is rugged, reliable and easy to use. The M1928 version, of gangster fame, was less reliable (UR), but could carry a 50 round drum magazine.
Possibly covers legs
Possibly cover legs. Good for road rash, stopping knives, etc. A good .38 slug will probably rip you to bits, however.
Can be worn unnoticably under most street clothes. Will stop most rounds up to a .45 ACP.
Personal protection for the fashion conscious, these lightweight Kevlar jackets ahve nylon coverings that resemble normal jackets.
Personal protection for the fashion conscious, these lightweight Kevlar jackets ahve nylon coverings that resemble normal jackets.
Standard protection for combat soldiers, the flack vest is designed to stop small arms fire, grenade shrapnel, but only slow up assault rifle rounds.
Standard protection for combat soldiers, the flack vest is designed to stop small arms fire, grenade shrapnel, but only slow up assault rifle rounds.

Heavy duty protection for the head, standard for most military. Some are made of steel, other of kevlar and high impact plastics. Most (90%) have face shields with 1/2 the SP level as the rest of the helmet.
Personal protection for the fashion conscious, these lightweight Kevlar jackets ahve nylon coverings that resemble normal jackets.
Heavy duty protection for stationary positions, like machinegun nests, helicopter doors, etc.
Laminated expoxide plate armour. Bulky and designed in modular sections, with helmet, arm & leg coverings, torso and back clamshell.

Want all the advantages of getting cyberoptics, but without the humanity loss? Smartgoggles can be outfitted with chips to simulate the effects of up to 4 cyberoptic options (each option costs the same as a cyberoptic option, less 10%). Smartgoggles come with a smartgun plug and cables, allowing the Targeting scope option to be used (+1 to ranged attacks).
A linear frame is a powered exoskeleton, giving the user tremendous strength. There are three levels of linear frames: Sigma, Beta and Omega.
Sigma - Strength 12 - Cost 5000.00
Beta - Stength 14 - Cost 7000.00
Omega - Strength 16 - Cost 9000.00

Normally, exoskeletons are worn as part of a cybernetics package (see Putting the Cyber Into The Punk, pg. 92 for more details). However, you can put on a linear frame without having it interfaced directly to you nervous system. Instead, you can simply chip into the suit as if it were any cyberbike or vehicle, taking a -2 REF penalty to do so.
Multiply the base cost by style:
Generic chic : 1x
This is the standard Streetwear, made up of colourful modular components in many colours. Belts, coats, sashes, boots predominate.
Leisurewear : 2x
This is the equivalent of 21st century athletic wear. Padded fleece, corporate and athletic logos.
Buisnesswear : 3x

This is the equivalent of the standard business suit; understated colours, pinstripes, real leather shoes etc. Wool and other natural fabrics are considered the proper outfitting for the up and coming Corp.
High Fashion: 4x
Sophisticated and expensive dressing for the upper class. Designer labels like Miyake, Si-fui Yan, and Anne Calvin.
Urban Flash: 2x
Video jackets, colourshift fabrics, cammo, leathers, metal spikes, Logowear, jeans, leather skirts, boots. The wildest and most utterly chilled in cyberfashion.
Multiply the base cost by style:
Generic chic : 1x
This is the standard Streetwear, made up of colourful modular components in many colours. Belts, coats, sashes, boots predominate.
Leisurewear : 2x
This is the equivalent of 21st century athletic wear. Padded fleece, corporate and athletic logos.
Buisnesswear : 3x

Urban Flash: 2x

Leisurewear : 2x

Buisnesswear : 3x

This is the equivalent of the standard business suit; understated colours, pinstripes, real leather shoes etc. Wool and other natural fabrics are considered the proper outfitting for the up and coming Corp.
High Fashion: 4x
Sophisticated and expensive dressing for the upper class. Designer labels like Miyake, Si-fui Yan, and Anne Calvin.
Urban Flash: 2x
Video jackets, colourshift fabrics, cammo, leathers, metal spikes, Logowear, jeans, leather skirts, boots. The wildest and most utterly chilled in cyberfashion.

A small handheld microcomp with various I/O connecters and probes. Techscanners run diagnostic programs, identify and examine malfunctioning components, and display internal schematics on a small screen.
Common oxy/acetalyne type out of a bottle. Hand held, about a foot long. More powerful models are available, up to themite lances at 5x-15x cost.
Mixed kit of tools for repair of mechanical items, usually in a 4"x16"x2" case.
Mixed kit of tools for repair of electronical items, usually in a 4"x16"x2" case.
Protective eyewear for welding, metal machining work, chemical mixing, etc.
A flashlight. You all know what this is. Beam range 100'-120'. Can buy smaller pocket lights (1/4 range) for half the normal price.
Chemlight in a 6" plastic tube. Shake or break to activate. Soft light last up to 6 hours. Comes in green, blue, red.
Fluorescent paint gives off soft light equal to Glowstik, lasts up to 4 hours.
Fluorescent tape gives off soft light equal to Glowstik, lasts up to 6 hours, comes in variety of widths.
Braided synthetics in a variety of thicknesses and weights. Can hold up to 1,000 lbs.
A common painter's style mask; nose and mouth coverage, with two recplacable filters (1 eb per 10 pack) on the sides. Good for keeping out the smog.
Small box (approx. 4"x2"x6" inches) projects a holographic picture from a replacable chip. Generator is compatible with chips from most digital cameras. Can be linked with a digital Recorder/Player.

Monitor using flat-LCD technology. No thicker than an inch, most video boards are build into TVs, but all types have input plugs for use as a readout monitor for other electronic products. Large ones (20'x100') are used as advertising signs. Videoboards are bought by the square foot.

The storage medium of the future for holding digital information. Usually plastic-cased, chips come in the shape of butons, flat squares, and triangular slivers. All shapes can be read by all types of recording media by use of adapter plugs.
Still images are "digitized" onto a chip cartridge. About the size of a pack of cigarettes.

Can be mounted on a headset, a shoulder clamp, or a hand-held depending on size (This affects price, size of recorded image, duration of recording time, etc. The price given is for the most inexpensive shoulder-carried model.) Sound and image are usually recorded on a tape-pak that is the size of a card deck or smaller, but you can direct-feed to a transmission device with a set of cables.
See electronic keyboard. (For more on the instruments of the 2010's-20's, check out the supplement Rockerboy.)
Little changes from the present, except in size and power.
See VideoCam. Note: the video tape of 2020 is a high density digital media capable of handling both audio and visual images.
This device plays the videocam tape-paks, along with many older-style audio tapes.
1 to 6 pop album favourites (or any other music) slapped into semiconductors and plastic. These chips are also available in a read-write format as well.

No longer the classic "axe", it's now lighter, a more flexible in its applications, and sometimes not even in a recognizable shape. It may have even replaced the strings and frets with a series of key banks!
Uses a flat-scan screen in a package 5"x5"x3/4" or smaller. Picks up the majority of VHF, UHF stations.
Common "new-wave" music equipment; a series of percussion pads and a sound box. It will fit in a couple of suitcases and can be arranged any way the drummer pleases.
This plays audio- and video-recorded chips. You must plug into a video board to play the video track of a digital chip.
Audio recording device using datachip technology, most are the size of two paperback books stacked flat. Some are smaller than a pack of cards.
A form of programmable inertial compass that keeps track of your changes in direction from a fixed bearing or point.

The common portable, with internal hard drive, video board (detachable), and slot for data/programming chips. These units do not have the advanced CPUs and memory spaces available in a regular computer system; they cannot be use for Netrunning.
The classic 6"x3"x1/2" programmable calculator with keyboard and chip slots, up to 100 pages of alphanumeric memory.
Special low-resistance/interferance cables for improved data transfer; they confer a +1 bonus on any interfacing tasks, such as controlling cybervehicles or Netrunning.

A computer workstation including keyboard, video board, and I/O connectors. A terminal can be used to Netrun (making the runner immune to most Black software), but is very, very slow (-5 to Interface skills). Terminal operators are commonly known as "net-tortoises".
Can be accessorized to your cyber modem or other electronic equipment.
See Netrunning Section, pg.133
A low efficiency headset for 'piggybacking' in the Net. -2 to Interface skill.
See Netrunning Section, pg.133
All commos are radio transceivers. This one is glued to the ajw and temple; you send via subvocalizazion and receive with soundless vibrations. Range 10 miles.
It fits in a cigarette pack.
Communication on the move, anywhere within reach of a radiotelephone transceiver network. There is a 100eb per month phone service charge.
A typical small walkie-talkie. Range 10 miles.
These high-tech vison aids combine binocular effects with a laster rangefinder, and sometimes IR lenses. More expensive versions will have a digital camera built in.
'nuff said.
See IR Goggles. UV flash is similar; also useable with the proper cyberoptic.
These pick up hazy, background Infrared sources. Normally used with an active IR source for invisible illumination.

Light intesification goggles boost ambient light for a night vision via 'Stalite' technology. Goggles can be overwhelmed by sudden light level increase. With tuning (DIFFICULT task) they can also detect active IR beams.
Cost: multiply by level of restaurant or bar:
Fair: 1x
Good: 2x
Excellent: 3x
Cost: multiply by level of restaurant or bar:
Fair: 1x
Good: 2x
Excellent: 3x

Portal Security. The keylock is a mechical lock and must be attacked that way. It has four increasing levels of complexity, and a single security system may incorporate all three types of locks (key/card/voco).
Type - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Difficult Level
Low Security - - - - - - - - - - - Average (15)
Medium Security - - - - - - - Difficult (20)
High Security - - - - - - - - - - - Very Difficult (25)
Maximum Security - - - - - - Nearly Impossible (30)

Portal Security. The cardlock is an electrical lock that uses a magnetically-coded card. It has four increasing levels of complexity, and a single security system may incorporate all three types of locks (key/card/voco).
Type - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Difficult Level
Low Security - - - - - - - - - - - Average (15)
Medium Security - - - - - - - Difficult (20)
High Security - - - - - - - - - - - Very Difficult (25)
Maximum Security - - - - - - Nearly Impossible (30)

A device that can pick up voice or data transmissions from a telecommunications line, then record or transmit them. The more sophisticated models need not be directly connected to the line they're monitoring (they will work up to a foot or so away), and can be remote controlled. Line taps cannot be used on systems installed or updated after 2008 due to the complete switchover to fiber optics.
A reading device for palmprint locks. Can be attached to any type of Card or Vocolock to add an extra layer of security.

Portal Security. The vocolock is a electronic lock that employs voice-recognition technology. It has four increasing levels of complexity, and a single security system may incorporate all three types of locks (key/card/voco).
Type - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Difficult Level
Low Security - - - - - - - - - - - Average (15)
Medium Security - - - - - - - Difficult (20)
High Security - - - - - - - - - - - Very Difficult (25)
Maximum Security - - - - - - Nearly Impossible (30)
Usually comes in 2 or 3 large cases, but can fill an entire van. James electromagnetic transmission in a 1000 fot area (that includes cellular phones and some cyberwear.)
The probe of this device is interested into a card lock instead of the normal card. A decryptor operates by adding +5 to your basic TECH+Electronic Security+1d10 skill check against the lock.
A vocal modulator for penetrating vocolocks. A decryptor operates by adding +5 to your basic TECH+Electronic Security+1d10 skill check against the lock.
Can be set to check out air or liquid for a specific poison(s). Otherwise, it will simply alert you to foreign substances. 85% accuracy.
The most common unlocking device for a cardlock.

A typical alarm system. Covers seismic, sonar, and fixed IR or visible light netowrks. Detects movement in a defined area, with a 95% reliability. The sensory precessor is about the size of a pack of cigarettes.
Hand held or suitcased equipment for detecting/following tracer buttons. Range is 1 mile.
This device searches out electromagnetic fields generated by various alarm systems (75% change of location). A TECH or INT roll maybe needed to identify the style of alarm encountered.

Can be any size from a matchbook to a pin. Uses radioactivity or constant/pulsed radio transmission to pinpoint who or what it's attached to. Some can be turned on/off remotely. Usually bought in sets of 6.

Great for riot control. One-use-only plastic locking strips for temporary handcuffs and leg ties (VERY DIFFICULT to break). With ceramic fibers to resist cutting, and guaranteed fireproof. Come in boxes of 12.
Just what it says. Probably a little stronger (a NEARLY IMPOSSIBLE task to break) due to new alloys. Often (50%) opened with a form of cardlock.
This automatically pulls the sides of a wound together and sutures it with stables of a compressed organic material that dissolves after an elapses time.
A putty-like spray gel for treatment of severe abrasions. Antiseptic and sterile, it's also air permeable and flakes off in about two weeks.
A small plastic pad containing a measured amount of medicine. The pad is applied to the skin and the medicine is absorbed in steady doses. See the Trauma Team section for drugs and prices.
Standard doctor's or military corpsman's bag. It contains antidotes, dressings, drugs, applicators, medicines, and examining instruments (probes, depressors, ocular light, stethoscope).

An advanced refridgeration tank; the cryotank will cool a body down to preservation levels while life-support machines maintain the blood/oxygen flow. Designed to keep a dying body in relative statis.
A full set of surgeon's tools (scalpel, retractor, probe, clamp, tweezer, etc.) and chemicals or equipment for maintaining a sterile operating field.
The common household medic's box. It has bandages, antiseptics, and a simple painkiller.
Readouts for body temperature, heartrate, blood pressure, respiration, and blood sugar levels. A small chipped database add a +2 to your Diagnose skill.

Ranging in size from a book to a briefcase, this gadget operates in a manner similar to the chemical sniffer. It will determine the purity of a drug with a known composition, or identify the molecular makeup and possible effects of an unknown substance that is similar to a drug already programmed into its library.
The "Bones McCoy" uses quick burst of compressed air to force a liquid drug through the skin. See the Trauma Team section for drugs and prices.
The athletic bag/kitbag of the 2000's, with a variety of logos to choose from. Sizes vary.
They're lighter weight, and can now take temperatures down to -100F. Compresses to a 12"x6"x4" wad.
Small preprogrammed robotic cleaning device. Usually about the size of a portable cannister vacuum. Not too smart.
Self-inflating, highly-compressed mattress package. About 6"x2"x4" folded.
Portable folding bed and pad; of Japanese origin.
Voice-activated controls for lights and appliances.
What more can we say?

10'x10'x8' living module in which all major furnishings and appliances are hidden in flush wall recesses and are extended only for use. Contains bed, closet, smallstove, refrigerator, TV and digital entertainment centre, two chairs, fold down desk, removable table. Rolls into place and can easily be transported. Cubes are usually so small that if you had all of your furnishings extended at once, there'd be no room for you to stand!
It gives light. Comes in an infinity of shapes and colours.
What more can we say?
Rapid (5 minute) battery-recharge for electric vehicles. Available at most service stations for 20 eb per charge.
2x cost for cybercontrols.

This is an updated, electrically powered version of the old Riva and Vespa motorscooters of the 1990's. Top speed about 50 mph, scooters can get about 6 hours of travel per fastcharge (about 5 minutes at any service station).
2x cost for cybercontrols.

These are updated versions of standard motorcycles. Most are recumbent designs, with plastic farings that close over the driver. About half are electrically powered, with top speeds of 65 mph and about 8 hours travel per fastcharge. CHOOH² powered versions have a top end of 140 mph and a four gallon tank.
2x cost for cybercontrols.

One man (two in a pinch), three wheelers common in the Corporate Zones. Top speed about 40mph, with 4 hours travel per fastcharge. CityCars can also be rented (2.00 eb per mile) from convenient kiosks located around most corporate areas; you use your debit card to rent from the vendor, drive where you want, and drop the car off at the nearest vendor.
2x cost for cybercontrols.
Almost always CHOOH² powered (electrics just don't have the speed). Top speed about 210, with a ten gallon tank. Seats 2.
2x cost for cybercontrols.
Usually methanol or CHOOH² powered, these vehicles have a top speed of around 90 mph, a ten gallon tank and seat four in relative comfort.
2x cost for cybercontrols.
Methanol or CHOOH² powered, these vehicles have a top speed of around 90 mph, a fifteen gallon tank and seat four.
2x cost for cybercontrols.
Methanol or CHOOH² powered, these vehicles have a top speed of around 90mph, a twenty gallon tank and seat six.
Synthetic meta-alcohol fuel. About 1d6/3+1 euro per gallon (the cost fluctuates wildly due to supply, demand and eco-terrorist activities).
A "debit card" that you can use to carry your cash around in instead of a wallet.

Just what it says. In the U.S., Britain, and some parts of Eastern Europe, the daily pollution gets so bad that you need to go to a miscellany of 'air bars', vendors, or streetcorner machines to buy a decent breath.

This is a curbside computer terminal, with access to news, weather, city maps, event schedules and other useful stuff. A DataTerm can also be used as a plug-in point to the Net. Terms are mounted in concrete pillars and are nearly indestructable. Theoretically.
A mass-produced nutrient that satisfies most requirements for sustenance, but tends to look, smell, and taste like the dry pet food it takes its name from.
You know what this is. Well, at least you've met someone who's eaten it.

A step-up from the common TV dinner, these meal packs can be microwaves or refrigerated depending on what's inside. Many come with their own chemtabs for heating or cooling. The cuisine isn't inspired, but it beats kibble.
Good restaurant meals in a package. The best quality pre-made meals you're going to find. For anything better, eat out, or prep it yourself (and who really knows how to do that anymore?).
Multiply base cost by location:
Combat Zone: 1x
Moderate Zone: 2x
Corporate Zone: 4x
Executive Zone: 6x

One step up from a sleeping bag on the street. A stacked accomodation which resembles its namesake, these sleeping boxes are found in airports and flophouses worldwide. Usually coin-operated with a time limit, the coffin give you just enough room to turn around or read in bed; restroom accomodations to be found elsewhere. More expensive models will have a phone or mini-TV inside.
Multiply base cost by location:
Combat Zone: 1x
Moderate Zone: 2x
Corporate Zone: 4x
Executive Zone: 6x
